noun.description: A thing made to be similar or identical to another.
examples: the problem is telling which is the original document and which the copy

noun.description: A single specimen of a particular book, record, or other publication or issue.
examples: the record has sold more than a million copies
copy for the next issue must be submitted by the beginning of the month

noun.description: A blank booklet or notebook used for schoolwork.
examples: examinees will not be allowed to take pens, copies, or water bottles inside the test center
you need a stock of exercise copies, A4 refill pads, and maths copies

verb.description: Make a similar or identical version of; reproduce.
examples: each form had to be copied and sent to a different department

verb.description: Imitate the style or behavior of.
examples: lifestyles that were copied from Miami and Fifth Avenue
art students copied from approved old masters
she was such fun that everybody wanted to copy her

verb.description: Hear or understand someone speaking on a radio transmitter.
examples: this is Edwards, do you copy, over

origin: Middle English (denoting a transcript or copy of a document): from Old French copie (noun), copier (verb), from Latin copia abundance (in medieval Latin transcript, from such phrases as copiam describendi facere give permission to transcribe).
